impact: A malicious app may be able to access notifications from other iCloud devices
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: An issue existed where a malicious app could access a Bluetooth-paired Mac or iOS device's Notification Center notifications via the Apple Notification Center Service. The issue affected devices using Handoff and logged into the same iCloud account. This issue was resolved by revoking access to the Apple Notification Center Service.
credit: Xiaolong Bai (Tsinghua University), Luyi Xing (System Security Lab of Indiana University), Tongxin Li (Peking University), XiaoFeng Wang (Indiana University)

impact: An attacker with privileged network position may be able to perform denial of service attack using malformed Bluetooth packets
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: An input validation issue existed in parsing of Bluetooth ACL packets. This issue was addressed through improved input validation.

impact: Parsing a maliciously crafted unicode string with speech alerts enabled may lead to an unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: A memory corruption issue existed in handling of Unicode strings. This issue was addressed by improved memory handling.

impact: A malicious application may be able change the password of a local user
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: In some circumstances, a state management issue existed in password authentication. The issue was addressed through improved state management.
credit: an anonymous researcher working with HP's Zero Day Initiative

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in PHP 5.5.20, the most serious of which may lead to arbitrary code execution.
available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in PHP versions prior to 5.5.20. These were addressed by updating Apache to version 5.5.27.

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in PHP 5.5.20, the most serious of which may lead to arbitrary code execution.
available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in PHP versions prior to 5.5.20. These were addressed by updating Apache to version 5.5.27.

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in PHP 5.5.20, the most serious of which may lead to arbitrary code execution.
available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in PHP versions prior to 5.5.20. These were addressed by updating Apache to version 5.5.27.

impact: Remote attackers may be able to circumvent a time delay for failed login attempts and conduct brute-force attacks
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: An issue existed when processing keyboard-interactive devices. This issue was addressed through improved authentication request validation.

impact: A local user may be able to cause a system denial of service
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: A resource exhaustion issue existed in the fasttrap driver. This was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: Processing a sequence of unicode characters can lead to an unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: Memory corruption issues existed in processing of Unicode characters. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: Processing a maliciously crafted file may lead to an unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution
available: OS X Mountain Lion v10.8.5, OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in QuickTime. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: A race condition existed in Install.framework's 'runner' binary that resulted in privileges being incorrectly dropped. This issue was addressed through improved object locking.
credit: Ian Beer of Google Project Zero

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: A memory corruption issue existed in NTFS. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.
credit: Roberto Paleari and Aristide Fattori of Emaze Networks

impact: A malicious application may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: An issue existed in AppleGraphicsControl which could have led to the disclosure of kernel memory layout. This issue was addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: Parsing a maliciously crafted QuickTime file may lead to an unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution
available: OS X Mountain Lion v10.8.5, OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: A memory corruption issue existed in parsing of QuickTime files. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: Viewing a maliciously crafted Collada file may lead to arbitrary code execution
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: A heap buffer overflow existed in SceneKit's handling of Collada files. This issue was addressed through improved input validation.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: A memory corruption issue existed in IOGraphics. This issue was addressed through additional type input validation.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10 to v10.10.4
description: An issue existed in how Install.framework's 'runner' binary dropped privileges. This issue was addressed through improved privilege management.
credit: Ian Beer of Google Project Zero

impact: A remote attacker may be able to cause a denial of service
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.5 or later
description: An assertion issue existed in the handling of TKEY packets. This issue was addressed by updating BIND to version 9.9.7-P2.

impact: Cached authentication state may reveal private browsing history
available: OS X Mountain Lion v10.8.5, OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, and OS X Yosemite v10.10.4
description: An issue existed in caching of HTTP authentication. Credentials entered in private browsing mode were carried over to regular browsing which would reveal parts of the user's private browsing history. This issue was addressed through improved caching restrictions.

impact: Processing a maliciously crafted file may lead to an unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution
available: Windows 7 and Windows Vista
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in QuickTime. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.
credit: Ryan Pentney and Richard Johnson of Cisco Talos

impact: Processing a maliciously crafted file may lead to an unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution
available: Windows 7 and Windows Vista
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in QuickTime. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

available: Windows 7 and Windows Vista
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in QuickTime. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.
credit: Ryan Pentney and Richard Johnson of Cisco Talos

impact: Users may be tracked by malicious websites using client certificates
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed in Safari's client certificate matching for SSL authentication. This issue was addressed through improved matching of valid client certificates.
credit: Stefan Kraus of fluid Operations AG, Sylvain Munaut of Whatever s.a.

impact: AppleID credentials may persist in the keychain after sign out
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed in keychain deletion. This issue was addressed through improved account cleanup.
credit: Kasif Dekel from Check Point Software Technologies

impact: A malicious app may be able to intercept communication between apps
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed that allowed a malicious app to intercept URL scheme communication between apps. This was mitigated by displaying a dialog when a URL scheme is used for the first time.
credit: Teun van Run of FiftyTwoDegreesNorth B.V.; XiaoFeng Wang of Indiana University, Luyi Xing of Indiana University, Tongxin Li of Peking University, Tongxin Li of Peking University, Xiaolong Bai of Tsinghua University

impact: A malicious application may be able to spoof another application's dialog windows
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An access issue existed with privileged API calls. This issue was addressed through additional restrictions.
credit: Min (Spark) Zheng, Hui Xue, Tao (Lenx) Wei, John C.S. Lui

impact: A local attacker may be able to reset failed passcode attempts with an iOS backup
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed in resetting failed passcode attempts with a backup of the iOS device. This was addressed through improved passcode failure logic.

impact: Clicking a malicious ITMS link may lead to a denial of service in an enterprise-signed application
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed with installation through ITMS links. This was addressed through additional installation verification.
credit: Zhaofeng Chen, Hui Xue, and Tao (Lenx) Wei of FireEye, Inc.

impact: An attacker can send an email that appears to come from a contact in the recipient's address book
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed in the handling of the sender's address. This issue was addressed through improved validation.

impact: A person with physical access to an iOS device can reply to an audio message from the lock screen when message previews from the lock screen are disabled
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: A lock screen issue allowed users to reply to audio messages when message previews were disabled. This issue was addressed through improved state management.

impact: A malicious application may be able to leak sensitive user information
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: Applications could access the screen framebuffer while they were in the background. This issue was addressed with improved access control on IOSurfaces.
credit: Jin Han, Su Mon Kywe, Qiang Yan, Robert Deng, Debin Gao, Yingjiu Li of School of Information Systems Singapore Management University, Feng Bao and Jianying Zhou of Cryptography and Security Department Institute for Infocomm Research

impact: A person with physical access to an iOS device may be able to use Siri to read notifications of content that is set not to be displayed at the lock screen
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: When a request was made to Siri, client side restrictions were not being checked by the server. This issue was addressed through improved restriction checking.

impact: Visiting a malicious website may lead to user interface spoofing
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue may have allowed a website to display content with a URL from a different website. This issue was addressed through improved URL handling.
credit: Erling Ellingsen of Facebook, Łukasz Pilorz

impact: Visiting a malicious website may lead to user interface spoofing
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: Navigating to a malicious website with a malformed window opener may have allowed the display of arbitrary URLs. This issue was addressed through improved handling of window openers.

impact: QuickType may learn the last character of a password in a filled-in web form
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed in WebKit's handling of password input context. This issue was addressed through improved input context handling.

impact: An attacker in a privileged network position may be able to redirect to a malicious domain
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed in the handling of resource caches on sites with invalid certificates. The issue was addressed by rejecting the application cache of domains with invalid certificates.
credit: Yaoqi Jia of National University of Singapore (NUS)

impact: An attacker in a privileged network position may be able to leak sensitive user information
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: An issue existed with Content-Disposition headers containing type attachment. This issue was addressed by disallowing some functionality for type attachment pages.
credit: Mickey Shkatov of the Intel(r) Advanced Threat Research Team, Daoyuan Wu of Singapore Management University, Rocky K. C. Chang of Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Łukasz Pilorz, superhei of www.knownsec.com

impact: A local user may be able to read Safari bookmarks on a locked iOS device without a passcode
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: Safari bookmark data was encrypted with a key protected only by the hardware UID. This issue was addressed by encrypting the Safari bookmark data with a key protected by the hardware UID and the user's passcode.

impact: A local user may be able to cause a system denial of service
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: An issue existed in HFS drive mounting. This was addressed by additional validation checks.

impact: Processing a maliciously crafted text file may lead to arbitrary code execution
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: Memory corruption issues existed in the processing of text files. These issues were addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: A malicious application may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: An issue existed that led to the disclosure of kernel memory content. This issue was addressed through improved bounds checking.
credit: Cererdlong of Alibaba Mobile Security Team

impact: A malicious enterprise application can install extensions before the application has been trusted
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: An issue existed in the validation of extensions during installation. This was addressed through improved app verification.
credit: Zhaofeng Chen, Hui Xue, and Tao (Lenx) Wei of FireEye, Inc.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: A memory corruption issue existed in IOMobileFrameBuffer. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: A memory corruption issue existed in the kernel. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: A memory corruption issue existed in IOAcceleratorFamily. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A person with physical access to an iOS device may read cache data from Apple apps
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: Cache data was encrypted with a key protected only by the hardware UID. This issue was addressed by encrypting the cache data with a key protected by the hardware UID and the user's passcode.
credit: Andreas Kurtz of NESO Security Labs

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, and Apple Watch Edition
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities in OpenSSL
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in the node.js OpenSSL module prior to version 1.0.1j. These issues were addressed by updating openssl to version 1.0.1j.

available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in the node.js OpenSSL module prior to version 1.0.1j. These issues were addressed by updating openssl to version 1.0.1j.

impact: An attacker may be able to access restricted parts of the filesystem
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: A comparison issue existed in the node.js send module prior to version 0.8.4. This issue was addressed by upgrading to version 0.12.3.

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in svn versions prior to 1.7.19
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in svn versions prior to 1.7.19. These issues were addressed by updating svn to version 1.7.20.

available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in svn versions prior to 1.7.19. These issues were addressed by updating svn to version 1.7.20.

impact: An attacker may be able to bypass access restrictions
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: An API issue existed in the apache configuration. This issue was addressed by updating header files to use the latest version.
credit: Branko Äibej of the Apache Software Foundation

impact: Build notifications may be sent to unintended recipients
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: An access issue existed in the handling of repository email lists. This issue was addressed through improved validation.
credit: Daniel Tomlinson of Rocket Apps, David Gatwood of Anchorfree

impact: An attacker with a privileged network position may be able to inspect traffic to Xcode Server
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.4 or later
description: Connections to Xcode Server may have been made without encryption. This issue was addressed through improved network connection logic.

available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10.5 and OS X El Capitan v10.11

available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10.5 and OS X El Capitan v10.11

available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later

available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A certificate validation issue existed in NSURL when a certificate changed. This issue was addressed through improved certificate validation.
credit: Timothy J. Wood of The Omni Group

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the Intel Graphics Driver. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A malicious application may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An uninitialized memory issue in the kernel led to the disclosure of kernel memory content. This issue was addressed through improved memory initialization.

impact: The screen lock may not engage after the specified time period
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed with captured display locking. The issue was addressed through improved lock handling.
credit: Carlos Moreira, Rainer Dorau of rainer dorau informationsdesign, Chris Nehren, Kai Takac, Hans Douma, Toni Vaahtera, and Jon Hall of Asynchrony

impact: A malicious application may gain access to a user's keychain items
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in validation of access control lists for iCloud keychain items. This issue was addressed through improved access control list checks.
credit: XiaoFeng Wang of Indiana University, Luyi Xing of Indiana University, Tongxin Li of Peking University, Tongxin Li of Peking University, Xiaolong Bai of Tsinghua University

impact: An application may be able to bypass code signing
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed with validation of the code signature of executables. This issue was addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: Processing malicious data may lead to unexpected application termination
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An overflow fault existed in the checkint division routines. This issue was addressed with improved division routines.

impact: Connecting to a malicious web proxy may set malicious cookies for a website
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in the handling of proxy connect responses. This issue was addressed by removing the set-cookie header while parsing the connect response.
credit: Xiaofeng Zheng of Blue Lotus Team, Tsinghua University

impact: A local user may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed that led to the disclosure of kernel memory layout. This was addressed through improved initialization of kernel memory structures.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A memory corruption issue existed in DiskImages. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A user connected through screen sharing can send Apple Events to a local user's session
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed with Apple Event filtering that allowed some users to send events to other users. This was addressed by improved Apple Event handling.

impact: A local attacker may be able to observe unprotected multipeer data
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in convenience initializer handling in which encryption could be actively downgraded to a non-encrypted session. This issue was addressed by changing the convenience initializer to require encryption.

impact: An attacker with a privileged network position may be able to extract payload from eSCL packets sent over a secure connection
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in the processing of eSCL packets. This issue was addressed through improved validation checks.

impact: A local attacker may gain access to keychain items
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in backups by the Time Machine framework. This issue was addressed through improved coverage of Time Machine backups.

impact: A malicious Game Center application may be able to access a player's email address
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in Game Center in the handling of a player's email. This issue was addressed through improved access restrictions.

impact: A maliciously crafted URL may be able to bypass HSTS and leak sensitive data
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A URL parsing vulnerability existed in HSTS handling. This issue was addressed through improved URL parsing.
credit: Xiaofeng Zheng of Blue Lotus Team, Tsinghua University

impact: An attacker with a privileged network position may be able to intercept network traffic
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in the handling of HSTS preload list entries in Safari private browsing mode. This issue was addressed through improved state handling.
credit: Rosario Giustolisi of University of Luxembourg

impact: A malicious website may be able to track users in Safari private browsing mode
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in the handling of HSTS state in Safari private browsing mode. This issue was addressed through improved state handling.

impact: Playing a malicious audio file may lead to an unexpected application termination
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A memory corruption issue existed in the handling of audio files. This issue issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local attacker may be able to read kernel memory
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A memory initialization issue existed in the kernel. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in IOAudioFamily that led to the disclosure of kernel memory content. This issue was addressed by permuting kernel pointers.

impact: A malicious application may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in IOGraphics which could have led to the disclosure of kernel memory layout. This issue was addressed through improved memory management.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in IOHIDFamily. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in IOHIDFamily. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the Kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.
credit: Cererdlong of Alibaba Mobile Security Team

impact: An attacker in a local LAN segment may disable IPv6 routing
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An insufficient validation issue existed in the handling of IPv6 router advertisements that allowed an attacker to set the hop limit to an arbitrary value. This issue was addressed by enforcing a minimum hop limit.

impact: A local user may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in debugging interfaces that led to the disclosure of memory content. This issue was addressed by sanitizing output from debugging interfaces.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: Processing a maliciously crafted font file may lead to arbitrary code execution
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A memory corruption issue existed in the processing of font files. This issue was addressed through improved input validation.

impact: A local user may be able to leak sensitive user information
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A cross-site scripting issue existed in parsing text by the Notes application. This issue was addressed through improved input validation.

impact: A malicious application may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A memory corruption issue existed in dyld. This was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with system privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the Intel Graphics Driver. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to leak sensitive user information
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in parsing links in the Notes application. This issue was addressed through improved input validation.
credit: Craig Young of Tripwire VERT, an anonymous researcher

impact: An attacker may be able to launch denial of service attacks on targeted TCP connections without knowing the correct sequence number
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in xnu's validation of TCP packet headers. This issue was addressed through improved TCP packet header validation.

impact: Many SSH connections could cause a denial of service
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: launchd had no limit on the number of processes that could be started by a network connection. This issue was addressed by limiting the number of SSH processes to 40.

impact: A local process can modify other processes without entitlement checks
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed where root processes using the processor_set_tasks API were allowed to retrieve the task ports of other processes. This issue was addressed through additional entitlement checks.
credit: Pedro Vilaça, working from original research by Ming-chieh Pan and Sung-ting Tsai; Jonathan Levin

impact: Maliciously crafted text could mislead the user in Terminal
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Terminal did not handle bidirectional override characters in the same way when displaying text and when selecting text. This issue was addressed by suppressing bidirectional override characters in Terminal.

impact: An attacker in a privileged network position may be able to intercept attachments of S/MIME-encrypted e-mail sent via Mail Drop
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in handling encryption parameters for large email attachments sent via Mail Drop. The issue is addressed by no longer offering Mail Drop when sending an encrypted e-mail.
credit: John McCombs of Integrated Mapping Ltd

impact: An attacker in a privileged network position can track a user's activity
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A cross-domain cookie issue existed in the handling of top level domains. The issue was address through improved restrictions of cookie creation.
credit: Xiaofeng Zheng of Blue Lotus Team, Tsinghua University

impact: A remote server may prompt for a certificate before identifying itself
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Secure Transport accepted the CertificateRequest message before the ServerKeyExchange message. This issue was addressed by requiring the ServerKeyExchange first.
credit: Benjamin Beurdouche, Karthikeyan Bhargavan, Antoine Delignat-Lavaud, Alfredo Pironti, and Jean Karim Zinzindohoue of INRIA Paris-Rocquencourt, and Cedric Fournet and Markulf Kohlweiss of Microsoft Research, Pierre-Yves Strub of IMDEA Software Institute

impact: A local user may be able to gain root privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A restriction issue existed in the Install private framework containing a privileged executable. This issue was addressed by removing the executable.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in the usage of environment variables by the rsh binary. This issue was addressed by dropping setuid privileges from the rsh binary.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A memory corruption issue existed in the kernel. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local user may be able to determine kernel memory layout
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in SMBClient that led to the disclosure of kernel memory content. This issue was addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: A trust evaluation configured to require revocation checking may succeed even if revocation checking fails
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: The kSecRevocationRequirePositiveResponse flag was specified but not implemented. This issue was addressed by implementing the flag.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the Kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: A local attacker may be able to inject arbitrary code to processes loading the Address Book framework
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in Address Book framework's handling of an environment variable. This issue was addressed through improved environment variable handling.
credit: Dan Bastone of Gotham Digital Science

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A memory corruption issue existed in the kernel. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.
credit: Lufeng Li of Qihoo 360 Vulcan Team

impact: A malicious application can prevent some systems from booting
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed with the addresses covered by the protected range register. This issue was fixed by changing the protected range.
credit: Xeno Kovah & Corey Kallenberg from LegbaCore

impact: The "Secure Empty Trash" feature may not securely delete files placed in the Trash
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in guaranteeing secure deletion of Trash files on some systems, such as those with flash storage. This issue was addressed by removing the "Secure Empty Trash" option.

impact: A local user may be able to cause a system denial of service
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A state management issue existed in debugging functionality. This issue was addressed through improved validation.
credit: Sergi Alvarez (pancake) of NowSecure Research Team

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the Kernel. These issues were addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: Malicious FTP servers may be able to cause the client to perform reconnaissance on other hosts
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An issue existed in the handling of FTP packets when using the PASV command. This issue was resolved through improved validation.

impact: An attacker may be able to replay Kerberos credentials to the SMB server
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: An authentication issue existed in Kerberos credentials. This issue was addressed through additional validation of credentials using a list of recently seen credentials.
credit: Tarun Chopra of Microsoft Corporation, U.S. and Yu Fan of Microsoft Corporation, China

impact: A malicious Apple Ethernet Thunderbolt adapter may be able to affect firmware flashing
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Apple Ethernet Thunderbolt adapters could modify the host firmware if connected during an EFI update. This issue was addressed by not loading option ROMs during updates.
credit: Trammell Hudson of Two Sigma Investments and snare

impact: The lock state of the keychain may be incorrectly displayed to the user
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A state management issue existed in the way keychain lock status was tracked. This issue was addressed through improved state management.
credit: Peter Walz of University of Minnesota, David Ephron, Eric E. Lawrence, Apple

impact: A remote attacker may be able to deny service to the FTP server
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: A glob-processing issue existed in tnftpd. This issue was addressed through improved glob validation.

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities in ICU
available: Mac OS X v10.6.8 and later
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in ICU versions prior to 53.1.0. These issues were addressed by updating ICU to version 55.1.
credit: Mark Brand of Google Project Zero

impact: A person with physical access to an iOS device may be able to access photos and contacts from the lock screen
available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later
description: A lock screen issue allowed access to photos and contacts on a locked device. This issue was addressed by restricting options offered on a locked device.

impact: An attacker can exercise unused EFI functions
available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5
description: An issue existed with EFI argument handling. This was addressed by removing the affected functions.
credit: Corey Kallenberg, Xeno Kovah, John Butterworth, and Sam Cornwell of The MITRE Corporation, coordinated via CERT

available: iPhone 4s and later, iPod touch (5th generation) and later, iPad 2 and later

description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the handling of font files. These issues were addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: A malicious application may be able to elevate privileges
available: OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: A heap based buffer overflow issue existed in the DNS client library. A malicious application with the ability to spoof responses from the local configd service may have been able to cause arbitrary code execution in DNS clients.

impact: A developer-signed executable may acquire restricted entitlements
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.5 and OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: An entitlement validation issue existed in Managed Configuration. A developer-signed app could bypass restrictions on use of restricted entitlements and elevate privileges. This issue was addressed through improved provisioning profile validation.

impact: Processing a maliciously crafted font file may lead to arbitrary code execution
available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10.5, and OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in the handling of font files. These issues were addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: A local user may be able to cause unexpected system termination or read kernel memory
available: OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: Multiple out of bounds read issues existed in the NVIDIA graphics driver. These issues were addressed through improved bounds checking.
credit: Ian Beer of Google Project Zero

impact: A local user may be able to cause unexpected system termination or read kernel memory
available: OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: Multiple out of bounds read issues existed in the NVIDIA graphics driver. These issues were addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges
available: OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: A memory corruption issue existed in the kernel. This issue was addressed through improved memory handling.

impact: Visiting a maliciously crafted website may lead to cookies being overwritten
available: OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: A parsing issue existed when handling cookies with different letter casing. This issue was addressed through improved parsing.
credit: Marvin Scholz and Michael Lutonsky; Xiaofeng Zheng and Jinjin Liang of Tsinghua University, Jian Jiang of University of California, Berkeley, Haixin Duan of Tsinghua University and International Computer Science Institute, Shuo Chen of Microsoft Research Redmond, Tao Wan of Huawei Canada, Nicholas Weaver of International Computer Science Institute and University of California, Berkeley, coordinated via CERT/CC

impact: An Apple-signed binary could be used to load arbitrary files
available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10.5, and OS X El Capitan 10.11
description: Certain Apple-signed executables loaded applications from relative locations. This was addressed through additional checks in Gatekeeper.

impact: A remote attacker may be able to cause unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution
available: OS X Mavericks v10.9.5, OS X Yosemite v10.10.5, and OS X El Capitan v10.11
description: Multiple memory corruption issues existed in DNS data parsing. These issues were addressed through improved bounds checking.

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities in BIND
available: OS X Yosemite 10.10.5, OS X El Capitan 10.11.1 or later
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in BIND versions prior to 9.9.7-P3, one of which may have allowed a remote attacker to cause a denial of service. These issues were addressed by updating BIND to version 9.9.7-P3.
credit: Hanno Böck from the Fuzzing Project

impact: Multiple vulnerabilities in BIND
available: OS X Yosemite 10.10.5, OS X El Capitan 10.11.1 or later
description: Multiple vulnerabilities existed in BIND versions prior to 9.9.7-P3, one of which may have allowed a remote attacker to cause a denial of service. These issues were addressed by updating BIND to version 9.9.7-P3.

impact: A remote attacker may be able to bypass access restrictions
available: OS X Yosemite 10.10.5, OS X El Capitan 10.11.1 or later
description: An HTTP header field reference was missing from the configuration files. This issue was addressed by adding the HTTP header field reference to the configuration file.

impact: Some cards may allow a terminal to retrieve limited recent transaction information when making a payment
available: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch, Apple Watch Edition, and Apple Watch Hermes
description: The transaction log functionality was enabled in certain configurations. This issue was addressed by removing the transaction log functionality. This update additionally addresses the issue for Apple Watches manufactured with watchOS 2.

impact: Swift programs performing certain type conversions may receive unexpected values
available: OS X Yosemite v10.10.5 or later
description: A type conversion issue existed that could lead to conversions returning unexpected values. This issue was addressed through improved type checking.
